title: The World According to Bertie
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: As they made their way out onto Dundonald Street, Cyril raised his head and sniffed at the air. There were the familiar smells of Drummond Place, the smell of the gardens in the centre, the sharp smell of oil on the stone setts, a cooking smell from somewhere close by, the smell of damp.

title: Bertie Plays the Blues
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: He was proud of this smock, which had been given to  him by Nigel McIsaac, a fellow artist who had lived round  the corner in Dundonald Street. Nigel had been the kindest  of men, and had taken Angus under his wing when he  had first come to Edinburgh.

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Scones
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Clarence Street was all right, he thought, but it was not Saxe-Coburg Place, which lay a block or two away to the north; perfectly respectable, but hardly stylish. A good place, thought Bruce, to begin; although he himself had begun in Dundonald Street and had now, effort­lessly it seemed, climbed to the heights of Howe Street.

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Scones
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: where it was parked. Bertie thought this unlikely; he thought that he had seen their car in Dundonald Street but it had proved only to be one that looked like it. So unless it turned up, they would be likely to travel up in the 23 bus.

title: The World According to Bertie
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: You know how children are – they don't make very good witnesses. But he did say that the dog came bounding out of a lower basement in Dundonald Street, gave him a nip on the ankles, and then ran off into the Drummond Square Gardens."

title: Bertie's Guide to Life and Mothers
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Bertie spent the rest of the journey in a state of unconcealed  joy. When they got off the bus on Dundas Street, he ran  all the way along Cumberland Street, having promised his  father to wait for him at the Dundonald Street end. And once  Stuart had caught up with him, he then ran the remaining  distance to their front door and was waiting for Stuart when  he arrived.
